content.raw:
These viscous damping coefficients represent our best first order estimation of the actual viscous damping coefficients of the physical robot.  Based on discussion with BDI, we believe that these values are in the right order-of-magnitude range.

Thanks for feedback.
content.html:
These viscous damping coefficients represent our best first order estimation of the actual viscous damping coefficients of the physical robot. Based on discussion with BDI, we believe that these values are in the right order-of-magnitude range.

Thanks for feedback.

content.raw: OK, thanks. I guess we'll have to compensate for it then. But what about the other joints? I have a hard time believing that the knee joint on the actual robot has a damping of 0.1, whereas the hip joints have a damping of 10.
content.html: OK, thanks. I guess we'll have to compensate for it then. But what about the other joints? I have a hard time believing that the knee joint on the actual robot has a damping of 0.1, whereas the hip joints have a damping of 10.

Please increase the damping on all the joints, especially the joints with
0.1 damping currently.
content.html: Please increase the damping on all the joints, especially the joints with 0.1 damping currently.

content.raw: pull request #243 raises joints with 0.1 Nms/rad damping to 1.0 Nms/rad, leaves highly damped joints (10.0 Nms/sec) unchanged.
content.html: pull request #243 raises joints with 0.1 Nms/rad damping to 1.0 Nms/rad, leaves highly damped joints (10.0 Nms/sec) unchanged.

content.raw:
We still think that 10.0 Nms/rad is not a realistic value for joint damping and it is should be closer to 0.1 Nms/rad. 

The effective joint damping is usually quite low on a force controlled robot when the force loop is closed, because the force measured at the joint (either using a force sensor or a spring deflection) and is controlled by a feedback loop. 
The inherent damping and inertia of the actuator affect bandwidth, but not the joint torque. We have measured values of joint damping on our actuators when the force loop is closed much closer to the original 0.1 Nms/rad.

If the effort returned by the atlas_state is the effort measured at the joint (after the damping of the actuator and reduction), then we would be able to close the force loop on our side, however the set and returned effort seem to be same.

Inverting the damping using the measured velocity is hard because the velocity signals are poor.

Order of magnitude is usually a good guess, but the difference between 10 Nms/rad and  5Nms/rad is enormous for controller performance. We would prefer values measured by BDI with a closed force control loop.
content.html:
We still think that 10.0 Nms/rad is not a realistic value for joint damping and it is should be closer to 0.1 Nms/rad.

The effective joint damping is usually quite low on a force controlled robot when the force loop is closed, because the force measured at the joint (either using a force sensor or a spring deflection) and is controlled by a feedback loop. The inherent damping and inertia of the actuator affect bandwidth, but not the joint torque. We have measured values of joint damping on our actuators when the force loop is closed much closer to the original 0.1 Nms/rad.

If the effort returned by the atlas_state is the effort measured at the joint (after the damping of the actuator and reduction), then we would be able to close the force loop on our side, however the set and returned effort seem to be same.

Inverting the damping using the measured velocity is hard because the velocity signals are poor.

Order of magnitude is usually a good guess, but the difference between 10 Nms/rad and 5Nms/rad is enormous for controller performance. We would prefer values measured by BDI with a closed force control loop.

content.raw:
I agree that we should ultimately use measured hardware damping coefficients in our model, but given the short time span to VRC, the fact that lowering the damping coefficient in `lhy` joint causes simulation noise to destabilize current implementation of BDI dynamic controller (**lowering joint damping coefficient introduces more simulation joint velocity noise, such that when exiting dynamic WALK behavior, there's a higher chance of robot falling over when returning to STAND mode.  Though this might be improved by filtering joint velocity (pull request #260) or tuning stepping parameters in `AtlasSimInterfaceCommand`**) and the desire to keep simulation performance near real-time while maintaining overall simulation stability, I'd rather keep the final values in pull request #243 for VRC.

One thing we can try here is implementing force torque sensors at the joints with large damping values (lhy, mhx and uhz) and report the torque values as efforts in the state feedback.  Will that be helpful?
content.html:
I agree that we should ultimately use measured hardware damping coefficients in our model, but given the short time span to VRC, the fact that lowering the damping coefficient in lhy joint causes simulation noise to destabilize current implementation of BDI dynamic controller (lowering joint damping coefficient introduces more simulation joint velocity noise, such that when exiting dynamic WALK behavior, there's a higher chance of robot falling over when returning to STAND mode. Though this might be improved by filtering joint velocity (pull request #260) or tuning stepping parameters in AtlasSimInterfaceCommand) and the desire to keep simulation performance near real-time while maintaining overall simulation stability, I'd rather keep the final values in pull request #243 for VRC.

One thing we can try here is implementing force torque sensors at the joints with large damping values (lhy, mhx and uhz) and report the torque values as efforts in the state feedback. Will that be helpful?

content.raw:
Maybe, but after doing some tests today we think that any force control or feedback for damping compensation should be done around 1000 - 10000 Hz, which is not feasible with the current control approach. Especially if the signals are even a little bit noisy and my feeling is that the force torque sensors are extremely noisy.

The high damping parameters basically break our walking controller. Could a solution be that the damping of the PID controllers or the kp_velocity is implemented using the CFM constraint mixing (with a certain reasonable minimum and maximum), such that teams that use full body force control can set the damping to low values?
content.html:
Maybe, but after doing some tests today we think that any force control or feedback for damping compensation should be done around 1000 - 10000 Hz, which is not feasible with the current control approach. Especially if the signals are even a little bit noisy and my feeling is that the force torque sensors are extremely noisy.

The high damping parameters basically break our walking controller. Could a solution be that the damping of the PID controllers or the kp_velocity is implemented using the CFM constraint mixing (with a certain reasonable minimum and maximum), such that teams that use full body force control can set the damping to low values?

content.raw: ok, updated pull request #194 where [kp_velocity between 0.1 and 10.0 is passed to joint damping, any excess kp_velocity is treated normally](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/5dad7e202638d02e8f84124a26a2ff0c647c5c5d/ros/atlas_msgs/AtlasPlugin.cpp?at=issue_194#cl-1361).  can someone test it out?  thanks.
content.html: ok, updated pull request #194 where kp_velocity between 0.1 and 10.0 is passed to joint damping, any excess kp_velocity is treated normally. can someone test it out? thanks.

content.raw:
On second thought, this conflates the functionalities of control through `kp_velocity` and joint damping, it might not preserve behavior .  Setting `kp_velocity` to 0.0 actually results in 0.1 Nms/rad joint damping plus `kp_velocity` of -0.1 in the PID update unless we do something more complicated.

If we are indeed allowing teams to change joint damping coefficients, it's be better to keep this issue separate from control and create a ROS service call, allowing setting joint damping dynamically with reasonable bounds per joint.  As implemented in pull request #248.  This will prevent breaking existing control code as one should be able to recover existing damping coefficients.
content.html:
On second thought, this conflates the functionalities of control through kp_velocity and joint damping, it might not preserve behavior . Setting kp_velocity to 0.0 actually results in 0.1 Nms/rad joint damping plus kp_velocity of -0.1 in the PID update unless we do something more complicated.

If we are indeed allowing teams to change joint damping coefficients, it's be better to keep this issue separate from control and create a ROS service call, allowing setting joint damping dynamically with reasonable bounds per joint. As implemented in pull request #248. This will prevent breaking existing control code as one should be able to recover existing damping coefficients.

content.raw: Pull request #248 contains more discussion on this topic.
content.html: Pull request #248 contains more discussion on this topic.

content.raw: If I'm reading correctly, discussion in pull request #248 included the suggestion by @tkoolen that the BDI controller uses the ability to adjust CFM damping parameter very high (above suggested limits) as a work around to the noise introduced when running physics with time step and iteration parameters adjusted to run in real time. Can you confirm this? If so, it seems that we'd want to be able to do the same thing, and furthermore to know exactly what value is used by the BDI controller.
content.html: If I'm reading correctly, discussion in pull request #248 included the suggestion by @tkoolen that the BDI controller uses the ability to adjust CFM damping parameter very high (above suggested limits) as a work around to the noise introduced when running physics with time step and iteration parameters adjusted to run in real time. Can you confirm this? If so, it seems that we'd want to be able to do the same thing, and furthermore to know exactly what value is used by the BDI controller.

content.raw:
Hi @andy_somerville,

To clarify, BDI controller does not adjust CFM damping parameters dynamically nor change them above [current released limits](http://gazebosim.org/wiki/DRC/UserGuide#ROS_Services).  Pull request #248 is there because 1). we do not know what the right damping coefficients should be, and 2). it will make it easier for teams controlling over wire with higher latency (as opposed to BDI's latency free control implementation inside of AtlasPlugin).

Hope that makes sense.
John
content.html:
Hi @andy_somerville,

To clarify, BDI controller does not adjust CFM damping parameters dynamically nor change them above current released limits. Pull request #248 is there because 1). we do not know what the right damping coefficients should be, and 2). it will make it easier for teams controlling over wire with higher latency (as opposed to BDI's latency free control implementation inside of AtlasPlugin).

Hope that makes sense. John

content.raw: @andy_somerville, like @hsu mentioned, I didn't mean that the BDI controller is dynamically adjusting the CFM damping, it just needs it to be set to a fairly high but constant value for the BDI controller to work.
content.html: @andy_somerville, like @hsu mentioned, I didn't mean that the BDI controller is dynamically adjusting the CFM damping, it just needs it to be set to a fairly high but constant value for the BDI controller to work.

content.raw: @hsu thanks that helps a bit. @tkoolen you're suggesting that the urdf values for the "cfmDamping" tag are what they are to make the BDI controller work and would otherwise be lower. Correct?
content.html: @hsu thanks that helps a bit. @tkoolen you're suggesting that the urdf values for the "cfmDamping" tag are what they are to make the BDI controller work and would otherwise be lower. Correct?

content.raw: So we have been having some issues with the allowed limits for the damping users can set, @catkeson mentioned this issue on pull request #248 but it didn't seem to be answered. We are also having problems with the ankle joint damping when using our controllers, we see a lot of vibration. We would appreciate an increase on the allowed upper limits.

content.raw: reopen to consider increasing the upper limits.

content.raw: I'd like to echo Chris Atkeson and Ghassan Atmeh that it's incredibly important for us to be able to significantly increase our joint damping.  We have been unable to get reasonable PD control due to some issues inherent in the low level PID control with DRCSIM that causes significant chatter/vibration due to the noisy D term.  Velocity filtering external to gazebo has not solved this issue.
content.html: I'd like to echo Chris Atkeson and Ghassan Atmeh that it's incredibly important for us to be able to significantly increase our joint damping. We have been unable to get reasonable PD control due to some issues inherent in the low level PID control with DRCSIM that causes significant chatter/vibration due to the noisy D term. Velocity filtering external to gazebo has not solved this issue.

content.raw: John has updated pull request #194 to increase the upper limit on joint damping, based on the effort and velocity limits at each joint, while limiting the number of times that damping can be changed per simulation. Please test it and give your thoughts.
